content.description: Sit start with your hands close to the right side of the block (see the pic). There is a detached block for your foot to start. Pull in, go left to get established on the face of the block, and top out.
content.protection: 2 pads, as the landing is sloped.
content.location: It is just to the south of the warm-up highballs.

content.description: Sit start low on a good jug at the base of the left arete, then climb straight up. This felt a little harder than Left Hook.
content.protection: 1 pad and a spotter. The landing is sloped, and it's hard to keep the pad from sliding.
content.location: It is immediately to the left of Left Hook and climbs the left arete of the boulder.

content.description: This is a warm-up for bouldering or for the aspiring free soloist. It's dead vertical, but holds keep popping up as you need it. Be careful of slipping on pine needles as you top out.
content.protection: Well, the landing is kinda bad, so just don't fall! I guess you can pad it out and use a spotter?
content.location: Start at the bottom just to the left of the arete below the block on the left.

content.description: Start at the arete of the crag, and climb straight up.
content.protection: Well, use a toprope or be confident at the grade.
content.location: It's in the middle of the highball face.

content.description: There is a steep slope that separates the South and North Sides. The tallest (but pretty easy) face is on the South Side.
